Recorded in the collection in 1713. Attribution contested by Blunt

Bought by the National Gallery in 1831. Re-dated to 1626–1627 from a brand on the back.

Acquired by the duc d'Aumale as part of Frédéric Reiset's collection
The Destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem

Painted for cardinal Barberini, who paid Poussin 61 écus for it on 3 February 1626. Passed into cardinal Richelieu's collection, lost at the end of the 18th century. Rediscovered in 1995 and given to the Israel Museum in 1999
View of Grottaferrata, made up of Venus and Adonis and Landscape with a river god
Dal Pozzo collection. Cut into two parts in the 18th century and reunited in 2009
Rome, Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, palazzo Barberini

Descent from the cross or The deposition from the cross
Bought by the duc d'Aumale in England in 1859
oil on copper, formerly in the Barberini collection. Sold at auction for $6.7 million to a private buyer in January 1999

Located in Paris in 1674, then Potsdam in 1773

Acquired by the French royal collection before 1683. Attribution rejected by Anthony Blunt

Venus and Mercury, made up of Venus and Mercury (image, left) and Concert of loves
Original composition known through a drawing in the Louvre. Cut up during the 18th century.
Dal Pozzo collection. Pendant to the Piéta at Cherbourg, repainted
Dal Pozzo collection. Pendant to the Brighton Virgin and Child
Originally used for Bacchus-Erigone, then painted over by Poussin with a Bacchus-Apollo. Much later repainting, to cover the figures' genitalia.

Copy of the Moscow painting considered to be by Poussin himself

The shepherds of Arcadia (Et in Arcadia ego)
Bacchanal with guitar player or The Great Bacchanal
Painted for cardinal Francesco Barberini. Owned by his heirs until its sale to present owner in 1958
Attribution supported by Blunt but rejected by Thuillier
Commissioned in 1628 at the instigation of cardinal Francesco Barberini for a side chapel of Saint Peter's basilica
Formerly in the Dal Pozzo collection
Saint James the Great's vision of the Virgin Mary
Possibly painted as an altarpiece for the église Saint-Jacques in Valenciennes. Bought by the duc de Richelieu then entered the French royal collection in 1665

Fragment d'une plus grande toile dont le sujet reste inconnu. In Pierre Crozat's collection, collection acquired by Catherine II of Russia

Finished at the end of 1630 and sold for 110 écus. Formerly in the collection of cardinal Richelieu
Nymph riding a goat or Venus, faun and putti

Sold for 100 écus. Collections of the elector of Saxony from 1722
Acquired in Paris in 1765 by Catherine II of Russia

Provenance prior to acquisition by Dulwich unknown. Attribution doubted by Mahon, Blunt and Thuillier
The miraculous translation of saint Rita of Cascia or The Virgin protecting Spoleto
Acquired in 1742 in Paris by Augustus of Saxony. Signed Accad. rom. Nicolaus Pusin faciebat Romae 1633
Possibly from the collection of Joshua Reynolds, passed to the Beauchamp family, entered the National Gallery in 1957. Signed N. Poussin fe. sur la pierre au premier plan.

Paid 70 écus for it on 2 September 1634 by a close contact of the pope. Passed into Richelieu's collection then the French royal collection in 1665
Landscape with ruins or Landscape with an ancient tomb and two figures

The Triumph of Neptune or The Birth of Venus (Richelieu Bacchanals I)
From a series commissioned by cardinal Richelieu for his château of the same name.
The Triumph of Silenus (Richelieu Bacchanals II)

From a series commissioned by cardinal Richelieu for his château of the same name. Considered to be an early copy (1637) of a lost original by Blunt, Thuillier and the National Gallery's curators. Considered to be an original Poussin by Rosenberg.
The Triumph of Pan (Richelieu Bacchanals III)
From a series commissioned by cardinal Richelieu for his château of the same name.
The Triumph of Bacchus (Richelieu Bacchanals IV)
Considered to be an early copy by Blunt and Thuillier. Considered to be a Poussin original by Rosenberg. From a series commissioned by cardinal Richelieu for his château of the same name.
Second in the series, preceded by Confession
The Seven Sacraments I : Extreme unction
dal Pozzo collection. Acquired by the dukes of Rutland in 1784–1785. Acquired by The Fitzwilliam Museum in 2012.
dal Pozzo collection. Acquired by the dukes of Rutland in 1784–1785

dal Pozzo collection. Acquired by the dukes of Rutland in 1784–1785.

Completed in 1642 in Paris. dal Pozzo collection. Acquired by the dukes of Rutland in 1784–1785. Separated from the rest of the series following a sale in 1939

Inscribed "Nicolaus Poussinus Andelyensis Academicus Romanus Primus Pictor Ordinarius Ludovici Iusti Regis Galliae. Anno Domini 1649. Romae. Aetatis suae 55" Painted for his friend Jean Pointel. Acquired by the Gemäldegalerie in 1821.
Inscribed "Effigies Nicolai Poussini Andelyensis Pictoris Anno Aetatis 56 Romae Anno Iubilei 1650" Painted for his friend Paul Fréart de Chantelou. Acquired by the French national collection in 1797.
Joined the French royal collection in 1685

Painted for Sérisier, then in the Seigneley collection, then in the collection of the ducs d'Orléans, finally acquired by Catherine II of Russia.
Walpole's collection before 1739. Acquired in 1779 by Catherine II of Russia
Possibly commissioned by the duc de Créqui. Formerly in the collection of the earls of Yarborough
